summary: This document is an email chain between a U.S. Attorney's Office representative and an attorney regarding a grand jury subpoena issued to William Hammond. The prosecutors seek flight records, observations of young women on flights, and information about Jeffrey Epstein's employees from Hammond, who is represented by counsel.

persons.name: William Hammond
persons.context: Recipient of a grand jury subpoena; the prosecutors are seeking flight manifests, travel records, and his observations regarding young women or girls on flights related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the investigation; prosecutors are seeking information about his relationships with young women or girls, his legal issues, and his employees from William Hammond.

connections.description: Hammond appears to have had access to flight records and potentially observations related to Epstein's travel; prosecutors are seeking information from Hammond about Epstein's activities and employees.

events.title: Initial subpoena return date
events.description: Original return date for the grand jury subpoena issued to William Hammond, which prosecutors offered to hold in abeyance.

events.title: Prosecutor follow-up on Hammond subpoena
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney sent a detailed email outlining the information sought from William Hammond, including flight records and observations about young women on flights related to Epstein.

keyFacts: Prosecutors sought flight manifests, plans, and travel records from William Hammond dating back to 2000 in connection with the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.
Investigators specifically asked Hammond for any observations of young women or girls on flights and any discussions with Epstein about his relationships with young women or his related legal issues.
The subpoena also sought the identities of Epstein's current and previous employees and staff known to Hammond.
The initial subpoena return date was July 22, 2019, but prosecutors offered to hold it in abeyance given the prospect of attorney proffer information or a voluntary interview.
